addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable S
r
Robert Cecill knight of her Hig
es
privy Councel.

26 N
o
1595 M
r
Bodley to my M
r
From
e Haghe./
A Pacquett intercepted in
e Mediterrane seas.
Rec. at
London
e viij
th
of
e same
Decembre.

page.lettertext:
fol.252r
May it please yo
r
H. to advertise her
Ma
tie
at
e
18 of this moneth, I receaved her gratious l
re
of the
4 w
t
an other to
e
states,
w
ch
according to my charge,
I presented unto them, in their publicke meeting, and
accomplished as muche, as I was otherwise enjoined,
by a verbal declaration. But
M
r
Caron
sent them
worde, above ten daies before,
at having had, as he rela-
ted, communication w
t
my
LL.
in case they would be
ready w
t
some succo
r
of shipping, against
e Spanishe pre-
paration, her Ma
tie
would be pleased, to lette fall for a
eason, her poursuite of remboursem
t
. Wherat
ei joied then
exceedingly, and reputed it expedient, to impart
e tidinges
out of hand, to
e
Provinces
abroad. W
ch
was done w
t
expedition, to meete w
t
many dangers, w
ch
it seemed, they
feared might growe upon
e soddaine, unles
e people by
some meanes, were put in better hart. But nowe I am
instructed, by
e l
re
of yo
r
H. that in this there was
an error, of too muche hast in M
r
Caron, before he had
receaved
her Hig
es
resolution. Having had among
themselves some time of consultation, up
o
e l
re
and de-
mandes, they delivered me an answear, w
t
speeches full
of thankes, and dutifull acknowledgemt, of
e grace that
they receaved, w
ch
could never have come, as
ei declared,
in a meeter season for their welfare. And tou-
ching
at w
ch
was required, of
e aide they were to yelde,
of 30 shippes of a certaine burden, they made no further
q
e
stion, but
at when it had bin moved to
e states in
particular,
ei would immediatly take order,
at her Ma
tie
should be served, to her best contentation. But for
the point of defraieng
e auxiliarie forces, they tooke it
altogether in
e self same nature, as her former demande:
w
ch
could by no meanes be effected, but by
e Generalitie
to whome
ei founde it all
e danger, to notifie
at her Ma
tie
fol.252v
will end her Treatie w
t
e contrey. I have urged
up
o
it w
t
divers replies,
at
e people might be wonne by
their good endeovo
rs
,
at it was not a thing to be stoode on,
at
the summe would be but smalle, yet esteemed to be great, in
regard of their willingnesse, and
e manifold occasions,
at
pressed her Hig
es
, and
e speeches
at would goe of this ne-
gotiation, w
t
divers other reasons, to w
ch
they gave no other
answear, then they have done heertofore, but
at they meant
to resume
e mater againe, and to examine it throughly,
and doe all
at
ei could, to satisfie her Ma
tie
. But as
for me I am persuaded,
at they will never yelde to any
thing, to howe litle soever
e summe be abridged, if it come
to be demanded, as a debt already dewe, by expiration of
the Treatie. For
at is
e place, where they thinke them-
selves wrunge, and
e people, they imagine, will by no
meanes endure it. For w
ch
I rest out of hope of any better
satisfaction: and to say w
at
I thinke, under humble cor-
rection, I hold it wholy requisit, to attend yet a while a fitter
opportunitie, w
ch
e state of thinges heere, and time must
present, or heereafter to project some suche forme of procee-
ding, as may come neerer to their liking, and yet c
o
clude
the full effect, of
at w
ch
is required. They have
secretly discoursed, about
e sending of some persons, to give
her Ma
tie
more c
o
tent, then hath bin done by their answear
delivered to me: and if it chance to be resolved, it is like
they will declare it, by some l
re
to her Ma
tie
. Wherof in like
sort, to interpose my opini
o
, w
t
out note of presumption, I should
thinke
at suche a message would make very muche for
e
service of her Hig
es
for
at in this case, where they can not
be persuaded, to assent to her demande, both
e sending of
their Deputies, will seeme more respective, in
e judgem
t
of
e world, then a bare kinde of writing; and it may be at
their coming, they will make some fruitfull motion, or be
fol.253r
wonne by good remonstrance, to reco
m
end heere at home,
some special purpose of her Ma
tie
or if neither of bothe should
happen, yet me thinkes in these sturres, and turbulent ti-
mes, where
e cause is so co
m
on between
e two contreis, her
Hig
es
can not but be holpen, by
e c
o
ference, and counsaile,
and presence of suche persons, as I presume
ei will Depute.
And where her Ma
tie
maketh mention of
Mr Bar-
nevelts
Ouverture, wherein there was good hope, both of this,
and greater maters, I have moved him about it, and de-
bated it at length: but he putteth me in minde,
at
e time
is farre other, and their state more afflicted, and
at they
have bin at
e charge
sins he and I talked of
of 2000
li
disboursed to
e
Frenche
kinges
use: and at great expenses in
e fielde, where
they had not then their armie, at
e time of
at Ouverture,
nor yet in 3 monethes after: and had perhaps, as he sup-
poseth, if
at plotte had bin accepted, remained still in garri-
son. W
t
all he doth maintaine (as I have formerly decla-
red, to be
e opini
o
both of him, and of divers heere besides)
That there is no possibilitie, to induce
e co
m
on sort, to con-
descend to resitution, by vertu of
e Contract: for
at they
will not understand it but as a mater of right, and a
just stipulation, and
at it ought to be c
o
tinued: for w
ch
of
force they must be wonne, by presenting unto them some other
forme of Treatie, w
t
some suche covenants, and conditions,
as neede not charge her Ma
tie
and yet tie
e contrey to
suche paiments, as her Hig
es
may require, in regarde of her
deboursments. And heere I can not by
e way,
but advertise yo
r
H.
at sins my last coming hither, I
have found M
r
Barnevelt farre out of temper, partly
through
e speeches of some of his collegues, w
ch
dislike of his
dealing, as if his ouverture to me had bin a motive to her
Ma
tie
when she sawe
at of themselves, they would yelde to
fol.253v
some good portion, to cast up
o
them
e burden of a greater
demande, wherew
t
they crushe
him
as he saith, very often in
their meetinges: partly also he is grieved w
t
somw
at
written
out of England, of
e opini
o
of some men,
at all his dealing
heere w
t
me, was but dalliance and cunning, to winne time
of her Ma
tie
w
ch
is also a touche to me in particular, in
respect of my credulitie, or some other imperfection, in
at I
could not see
e practise. But for my self, I could wishe
that
e mater then proposed, had come aswel in some forme
w
ch
her Ma
tie
could have liked, as it was cleere, and out of
question,
at there was no dissimulation. For as for any
abuse
at Barnevelt could offer, by meanes of
e ouverture,
it was so hard for him to doe it, and so many must con-
curre, and it had steeded him so litle, as if
e circ
u
stance
of thinges, in
e nature of
at cause, and in
e forme of this
gouvernment, and in
e maner of his c
o
ferring and procee-
ding heere w
t
me, be dewly weighed w
t
all his pointes, I
doe not thinke to finde any,
at will stand in
at opinion.
It is advertised hither, from very good place,
at
e Administrator of
Saxonie,
e
Elector of Mayence
,
e
Arche-
bishop of Saltzbourgh
, and
e rest
at are elected, to worke
the feat of Pacifaction, have c
o
cluded among themselves
to goe in hand w
t
that attempt, about Fe
b
next: w
ch
yet,
we thinke, will be differed, till
e coming of
e Cardinal,
who many men thinke will be longer in coming: because
they say, he hath in Province many irons in
e fire, and is
in hand w
t
Casot
e Consul of
Marseilles,
to deliver that
towne
to
e towne
to
e
K. of Spaine
. But for
the mater of Pacification, this people is inabled, by an ex-
cellent late token, of Gods goodnesse unto them, to choake
e
Enemie very soundly, and to dashe
at practise altogether,
For there hath bin very happely intercepted of late, in
e
fol.254r
Mediterrane sea, a special packet of l
re
s, w
ch
were written
by
e
Marquis of Havre
, and
John Bapt
a
Taxis
, to
e K.
of Spaine, and sent hither to
e states, by
Mons
r
d'Esdi-
guieres
. By
at of Taxis is discouvered a double fals-
hood in their meaning, both towardes
e
Empero
r
,
and
e
states: and also otherwise his l
re
, is full of fraudulent
courses. They were written bothe in cipher, and deciphred
in suche sort, as I have sent yow
e transcript, by
Mons
r
de S
te
Aldegonde
: and were by
e states delivered to me,
w
t
an earnest request,
at they might not be divulged
but to her Ma
tie
and my LL. to
e end, in time c
o
venient
they may serve to be produced, to
e advantage of their
purpose. Heere is secret notice given, and,
it is thought, over true,
at
e
Co. of Hohenlo
, who is nowe
in
Germany,
doth imploy all his meanes to
e advancement
of a peace: and is wholy busied among
e Princes, in ma-
ters prejudicial to
e state of this union: all proceeding
of dislike between him and
Co. Maurice
. Moreover it
is reported,
at he will meete
e
P. of Orenge
, whose sister
he hath maried, in his way to these contreis, and w
at
his
dealing may be further, it is feared of divers.
It is undoubtedly heere beleeved that there will be a truce
between
Spaine
and
France:
at
e lest for a yere.
We have also heere intelligence,
at
e Gouvernor of
Boullen
by
Calais,
hath suche doinges of late w
t
e
D. d'Espernon
,
as many men see cause, to doubt of his Loialtie. As they
doe in like maner of
e holding out of Calais, w
ch
is not so
provided, as
e place doth require: and sith we heare
at
de Fuentes maketh great preparati
o
, it is suspected heere of
many,
at he designe is to besiege it. The F. King
hath writt en to
e states, to knowe w
at
kinde of warre, they
will make
e next yere, whether Offensive or Defensive,
fol.254v
to
e end he may thereafter direct his owne affaires.
And their answear thereunto he desireth to receave, by his
Ambassado
r
Mons
r
Buzenval
, to whome he hath written to
returne w
t
e same, and to give him information of their state
in many maters. But I can not yet perceave,
at the
states can well determine, w
at
answear to returne, as-
touching their warre. Some of those in these
quarters,
at have best intelligence out of Spaine, give it out
for certaine,
at
e bruited preparations are nothing so
great, as heere they did imagine. To come to
at
last, w
ch
toucheth my self, I am to sue unto yo
r
H. very
humbly and earnestly,
at her Ma
tie
may be moved to
grant me licence to returne, wherein, before I went from
home, my
L. T
re
r
promised, to favo
r
my petition, and I
hope my
L. of Essex
will put his helping hand to it. For
I protest unto yo
r
H. if I might have but
e leasure, to
sette some order in my state, w
ch
is charged w
t
expenses,
more them most men doe imagine, and is many waies
wracked to my very great detriment, by reason of my
absence, it would to me be all a mater, to live at home, or
abroade, ether heere, or wheresoever, as her Ma
tie
may
be pleased, to thinke me fitte to serve her turne. And so
I take my humble leave.
Fr
o
e Hage
26 N
o
95
Yo
r
H. very humble at c
o
mandem
t
Tho. Bodley
